US street planners are looking for a source of money to repair the declining highway system , and believe that the solution has been found in a small black box that can be found in the fitting board of each car .

The equipment that records every kilometre driven and reports to the authorities is at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and the state planning offices to revise the outdated system for financing US roads .
The usually boring area of road planning has suddenly created an intensive debate with colourful alliances .

Libertarians have allied with environmental groups , and advocate that the government can use the small boxes to record the driven kilometres – and possibly where they were driven – and then use the information to calculate tax modes .
